docs.lead_paragraph: At the heart of the fight over health care legislation is a paradox that befuddles lawmakers of both parties. Separate bills passed by the Senate and the House would squeeze nearly a half-trillion dollars from projected spending on Medicare over the next 10 years. These savings would help offset the cost of providing coverage to people who are uninsured.

headline.main: Expanding Health Coverage and Shoring Up Medicare: Is It Double-Counting?

docs.abstract: Lawmakers on both sides are befuddled over whether separate bills passed by Senate and House, which would squeeze nearly half-trillion dollars from projected spending on Medicare over next decade, would help offset cost of providing coverage to people who are uninsured; Congressional Budget Office says same money cannot be used for both purposes (M)
docs.snippet: The issue involves not only technical accounting matters, but also a huge political issue: the impact of health care overhaul on Medicare and its beneficiaries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like about a dozen other states, Florida is debating a proposed amendment to its state constitution that would try to block, at least symbolically, much of the proposed federal health care overhaul on the grounds that it tramples individual liberty. But what unites the proposal's legislative backers is more than ideology. Its 42 co-sponsors, all Republicans, were almost all recipients of outsized campaign contributions from major health care interests, a total of about $765,000 in 2008, according to a new study by the National Institute on Money in State Politics, a nonpartisan group based in Helena, Mont.

headline.main: At State Level, Health Lobby Fights Change

docs.snippet: Like about a dozen other states, Florida is debating a proposed amendment to its state constitution that would try to block, at least symbolically, much of the proposed federal health care overhaul on the grounds that it tramples individual liberty. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a middle-class tax time bomb ticking in the Senate's version of President Obama's effort to reform health care. The bill that passed the Senate with such fanfare on Christmas Eve would impose a confiscatory 40 percent excise tax on so-called Cadillac health plans, which are popularly viewed as over-the-top plans held only by the very wealthy. In fact, it's a tax that in a few years will hammer millions of middle-class policyholders, forcing them to scale back their access to medical care.
docs.snippet: There is a middle-class tax time bomb ticking in the Senate's version of President Obama's effort to reform health care.      The bill that passed the Senate with such fanfare on Christmas Eve would impose a confiscatory 40 percent excise tax on...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was just an average busy, stressful day at work, in May 2004, when the deputy sheriff arrived with a summons. I sucked in my breath, signed the receipt and returned to my desk piled high with charts, messages, lab results and forms. I was being sued for medical malpractice. That was how it started. Eventually I peeked at the text of the complaint, which was riddled with accusations. Apparently, my conduct was ''malicious, willful, wanton or reckless,'' and I had ''negligently, carelessly and without regard'' for my patient's health treated her in such a manner that she had died the previous year.

headline.main: A Patient Dies, and Then the Anguish of Litigation

docs.abstract: Dr Joan Savitsky Cases column describes malpractice case brought against her after death of her patient, who had aggressive colon cancer; provides insight into what doctors go through when suit is brought against them; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor accused of “malicious” conduct in the care of a patient coped with practicing, and living, under the cloud of a medical malpractice lawsuit.
